page.title: 02LANDSCAPE N-W OF HEADCORN
page.content: The land is generally low lying and damp,ranging in height from 18m. near the River Beult to 34m. at Great Tong Farm. The{underlying rock is Wealden {Clay}so the land is undulating rather than spectacular although there is one small hill just N-W of the main village. There are many ponds in the area,some natural but several man-made pits from which clay was once dug and around which willows grow. Flowing from East to West is the R.Beult,a tributary of the Medway. It is only about 15m. wide and meanders very slowly through its flood plain. There are only two remaining{wooded areas}at New Barn and at Four Oaks Wood,but the area is scattered with many deciduous trees such as Ash,Willow and Field Maple. However,in the main they are Oaks,the remains of the great Wealden forest of Anderida .
